content: Prefers Slack to what though? :thinking:

thread.title: @MarcP, I heard you are helping us out with moving off Flowdock. Welcome to‚Ä¶

content:
@Ian, Just straight up prefer Slack (over Flowdock). All non-Finnish employees here in SF (i.e. employees not here on Visas from Finland) had: 

1. Never heard of Flowdock before joining Smartly
2. Used Slack at previous companies, so only have Slack to compare Flowdock against*

*If I had to make an educated guess, Slack is the most prevalent chat tool ‚Äúin Tech‚Äù so *it is the* most familiar chat tool for incoming SF employees.

Note that I‚Äôm not necessarily advocating for using Slack ‚Äújust because other companies use it"

Furthermore, a few SF employees are already using Slack with certain clients via single-channel feature.

Also, we don‚Äôt have any full-time developers here (outside of those on secondment/Visas, Miikka, Miika, Terho), so nobody here in SF generally cares if our replacement chat tool is open source where we can technically make our own integrations.

thread.title: @MarcP, I heard you are helping us out with moving off Flowdock. Welcome to‚Ä¶

content:
@Peter, Agreed. My $.02:

- Perhaps sometimes Transparency (or lack thereof) is confused "with information on a need-to know basis‚Äù

- I didn‚Äôt join Smartly because of the chat tool we use (or don‚Äôt use) i.e. I‚Äôll use whichever one Smartly says that I need to use...

- Asking everyone for their opinions clearly slows down the decision-making process: not just here but with other topics I‚Äôve seen since I joined Smartly in July 2019 >> [you‚Äôre] never going to be able to make 100% of the people happy with any decision [you] make

^^ I realize that this has been a huge part of Smartly‚Äôs culture *however* there reaches a point in an organization‚Äôs size where this is no longer scalable‚Ä¶..

thread.title: WIP flowdock thread analysis: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OVsts3‚Ä¶

content:
Thanks for the reply @MarcP! No arguments re: Flowdock but getting rid of it is (I understand) a done deal, so I guess I was wondering whether this pro-Slack sentiment included an implicit assessment of other alternatives.

I‚Äôm not sure to what extent open source, or an API is even regarded as a drawcard by most of our developers, who would surely prefer to be working on our product (see also: Dev Ops not particularly liking the sound of ‚Äúself-hosted‚Äù), but it‚Äôs a factor in considering the overall viability of a solution, I guess. If Flowdock were open source I doubt we‚Äôd be in the current situation, for example (at least not exactly), since fixing a few issues ourselves would be preferable to a costly migration. Anyhoo.

thread.title: @MarcP, I heard you are helping us out with moving off Flowdock. Welcome to‚Ä¶

content:
Yeah of course! @Ian 

And for the record, I‚Äôm not necessarily personally advocating for Slack (although it would be an easy transition for me because I‚Äôve used previously at my last 3 employers). The only other chat tool I‚Äôve used since joining the workforce is Hipchat (RIP)...

Re-stating the obvious: whichever tool we replace Flowdock with, we obvi need to perform our due diligence *since* we have so many integrations/configurations set up AND because so many people have strong opinions about it‚Ä¶.

Either way, this is going to be a fun rollercoaster of a ride‚Ä¶. üòé

thread.title: @MarcP, I heard you are helping us out with moving off Flowdock. Welcome to‚Ä¶

content:
@Ian, I think we were getting a bit ahead of ourselves with the action points from the openspace. I think it makes more sense to do an initial qualification of our options based on agreed "must have" requirements.

After that I might need your help looking at the short list of contenders.

thread.title: Completed my first analysis of the feedback: https://docs.google.com/spreadsh...

content:
@Peter, I'll help you out a bit ;)
- https://github.com/smartlyio/hubspot which is a webhook for Hubspot, with which we get notifications to the "Inbound Demo Requests" -flow.
- https://github.com/smartlyio/bi-etl streams data from Salesforce to our BI DB and if we win/lose an account/opportunity, we send a notification to Customers -flow.
- `FlowdockNotifier` which lives in Salesforce - whenever a CRM user posts f.ex. meeting notes to Salesforce, they are re-posted to "Customer Notes" -flow

content:
I'm still working on the scoring, I'd like to state publicly that I'm no fan of facebook workplace as a flowdock replacement. The chat in that tool is not even close to flowdock in terms of functionality ... it doesn't have threads at all.

The posts part is pretty interesting, but it's not integrated with the chats ... so that really interesting chat thread isn't going to rise up the news feeds and get attention (solving the thread visibility dilemma - should I team ping or not?)

I honestly don't get it!

content:
@Peter, just to keep you in the loop,
I‚Äôm going to start researching specifically into **Intercom-Slack integrations** starting next week.

Particular areas I will cover that are currently existing between Flowdock & Intercom include (may not be exhaustive),
1) Tagging someone in intercom notes -> Creates new thread in Slack Support flow and tags the person in the Slack thread.

2) @ mentioning a team in intercom creates a thread in a teams flow(Slack), e.g. @ Topgun

3) @ Support Investigator pings in intercom notes -> Creates new thread in Slack Support Flow and cc pings Tech support investigator on duty

All the above will have,
- Corresponding Intercom chat link attached to the new generated thread in slack.
- Slack thread url generated sent back to the intercom chat

Out of curiosity, is there a planned deadline for migration to Slack or any sort of timeline given?

cc. @MarcM

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content:
thanks for the update @Justin, sounds good and thanks for taking ownership.

One thing that needs to be carefully considered is threads vs channels. While I personally like using threads for everything, Slack's design is definitely different - channels are used more - so it's worth thinking about, especially since the Intercom integration is using channels.

Also, perhaps this is a good time to look at the current integration between Flowdock and Intercom. Personally I find the Support flow threads useless/confusing because the sync is only in one direction. I think that if it can't be made bi-directional then we should consider not having it at all, rather just ping the relevant people to go to the relevant chat in Intercom.

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content: about the project we'll have a kick off next week to discuss, but the general idea pre-corona was to get this project done "before summer" meaning by the end of June. I think that is still very do-able and I'd like to have things ready much sooner.

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content: I've created a Jira project for tracking my own work on this project, feel free to add your work there if it helps you organise: https://smartlyio.atlassian.net/jira/software/projects/SLACK/boards/186

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content: Careful thought needs to be put into the channels-approach. What exactly consists a channel and how we manage the amount of those. I feel there should be quite a bit of effort put into minimizing the amount of channels to follow, as not to get information sprawl and worsen even the current situation.

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content:
yes, I totally agree @Martti and we've agreed that we'll plan and communicate that kind of policy/guidance along with the migration.

That said the intercom guys have made a rather odd design choice with their plugin, which creates a channel per chat: https://www.intercom.com/integrations/slack

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content: Currently we have flows for teams, locations, and groups of teams. And some transient flows such as this one. Technically could be thought of as a team as well, as there's no Communications team flow.

content: yeah, I think we need to plan things up front taking into account things like the matrix org structure, but also recognise that the tool isn't exactly the same and we'll need to adapt

thread.title: @Peter, just to keep you in the loop,

content: having a) a search that works across channels, b) the ability to subscribe/unsubscribe to threads, c) a central place to read unread notifications across threads and channels makes quite a different in practice

content: I sent a support request about this import issue: https://work-smartly.slack.com/help/requests/2681963

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content:
> We are planning to move our companies Flowdock history to Slack when we migrate, but I'm having some trouble with the migration tool.

> Firstly when we use your tool to import a Flowdock Flow it mostly fails without any meaningful error. The result is that the users are imported correctly, but the channels are empty, or just have the first few messages.

> Is there any way to get a more meaningful error message or logs?

> Secondly, I did manage to import one small Flow however that revealed another issue. The import brings in all the messages, but looses all the threads. The messages are listed in the order they are sent, not grouped into threads - it's pretty useless to us since Flowdock threads are a way of life for us at the moment.

> Is this a known issue with your import tool, or is there some other problem?

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content:
> I'm sorry for the trouble with your Flowdock import. The error you ran into is, in fact, a bug that our engineers are currently working to debug. This is causing imports to fail after channel create but before all messages are imported. I brought your report to them and they're looking into the logs. As soon as there's an update, I'll let you know.
>
> Regarding the threads, this is expected. I'm afraid the import tool does not handle threads from Flowdock. I'll let the team know this is something you'd like to see improved, though I don't think it will be something that's addressed in the near future.
>
> I'll keep you posted on the bug with imports failing. In the meantime, I recommend holding off of importing anything as a private channel. It's not possible to merge into private channels with future imports, so this could results in duplicate private channels being created. It's fine to try importing as public channels, as these can be merged to with subsequent imports, though we can't guarantee the imports will be successful at the moment.

@Andrei Slack replied to my support request. Thread import doesn't work with their tool. The other issue is a bug they are working on.

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content: I think this leaves us with two options. 1) implement our own import that includes threads. 2) no import the history to Slack and handle the historical data in another way.

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content: I think I'll look at their APIs to see if option 1 is even possible

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content: @Peter, current import (flat) is also an option. Not the best of course, but still should be considered. Maybe we can import some channels and save history of other channels in other place. Good topic for the kick-off

thread.title: Uploaded File Import Data   Smartly io Slack.png

content: good point, but I don't think the flat import option is very useful because it's just impossible to figure out in a noisy channel what was said in answer to what. That said, if we export content elsewhere, like to ES, then we'll have similar issues unless we implement a thread-capable viewer

content:
@team Learnings from previous Flowdock to Slack migrations #notes

Present: @Leena @Ilkka @Peter @KataJ

Zendesk (@Ilkka)

- Transition to Slack was a phased migration over at least one month.
- no history was migrated, because the content wasn't considered critical (Flowdock wasn't their primary communication channel)
- Channel (re)naming was co-ordinated
  - Prefixes for channel names, `team-finance`, `ask-finance`
  - Non-critical flows were migrated quickly, others like DevOps, were done later
 - Integrations were the responsibility of the team
 - Minimal training given (again not their primary comms channel)
- The had a read only announcements channel which was good.

Unity (@Leena)

- Also had a phased migration period
- Each team had a Slack advocate for integrations, learning, change management
- They copied the Flows 1:1 to Slack, but in hindsight they should have renamed them at the same time. They had to do that separately later which was disruptive (twice)
- Good to have naming conventions for channels like `ask-finance` vs `talk-finance`. Prefix for communication purpose.
- Had no restrictions on creating new channels, but had a channel that logs all the new channels
- No history was migrated
- Flowdock was kept for some time to check history
- Standardise status icon emojis. e.g. working from home, taking care of kids
- Make good use of welcome bot/welcome message in channels to redirect common requests.

thread.title: @team Learnings from previous Flowdock to Slack migrations #notes

content: I suppose the naming prefix stuff is a result of them reading this: https://slack.com/intl/en-fi/help/articles/217626408-Create-guidelines-for-channel-names#create-channel-prefixes

thread.title: Not related to this project directly, but I just stumbled across https‚Ä¶

content:
@andrei learnings so far on this ... the slack exports work with threads (as you would expect), so it's only their Flowdock export tool that ignores the threads.

There is no meaningful documentation about how to format threads in their JSON format, but it's pretty easy to export an example for reverse engineering. I've asked their support if they can provide any more help than that.

It seems it would be possible to transform the Flowdock JSON to Slack JSON, and then import it. Figuring out the correct links to threads will require a bit of work, but I think it's doable.

One thing that is helpful is that we can do this on a Flow by Flow basis, so it's pretty easy to test and develop.

Whether we should do it ... that is a different question!
